Ultra-athlete Jure Robic pulls out a DVD and prepares to reveal the unique talent that sets him apart from the rest of the world: his insanity.

Since he could speak, 8-year-old Brandon has insisted that he was meant to be a girl. This summer, his parents decided to let him grow up as one.
Weve known for a long time that gravity doesnt exist [as a fundamental force] Dr. Verlinde said, Its time to yell it. Some of the best minds in physics are starting to agree with him...

Standing before the shack that destroyed Russia filled me with a weird terror. The place had the beaten look of a college sophomore's apartment. Yet I trembled when I walked up close enough to see the lettering on the door. Officials in Moscow had been machine-gunned for less...

The Mountains of Pi: The definition of a supercomputer is simply this - One of the largest and fastest computers on the planet. By that definition, the Chudnovsky Brothers had built a supercomputer in their apartment. With it, they would probe the mind of God...

Our main leisure activity is, by a long shot, participating in experiences that we know are not real. When we are free to do whatever we want, we retreat to the imagination. This is a strange way for an animal to spend its days.
Symphony in J flat: The curious quest to re-invent music
The British, never fond of children, have lost all knowledge or intuition about how to raise them; as a consequence, they now fear them, perhaps the most terrible augury possible for a society.

The Years of Lead: In the early 1980's Italy was menaced a group of well-connected and financed terrorists who adored Hitler *and* Mao and were led by a crazed aristocrat who based his philosophy on the Four Ages of Hinduism. They killed hundreds and largely escaped justice.

Russian leaders harbor grand ambitions of nurturing innovation, luring great scientists back to the country, and catching up with the developed countries. The problem is that the best and brightest Russians have little reason to return and many good reasons to leave....
Turkish Jews used by Israeli navy as translators give most even-handed account so far of raid on Gaza flotilla. Debunks wilder accusations about incident, suggests Turks, Israelis both to blame.
Something doesn't fit: Why are both Treasury bonds and gold performing so well? Current gold prices imply a treasury yield more than three times higher than the actual level.
Behavioural economist asks, and answers, two footballing questions: Why do players take dives so often and so obviously? And why do national styles of play persist over generations?

Although people have been worried about correct speech for thousands of years, it's apparently the status anxieties of modern societies that create the market for usage advice in which artificial "rules" can spring up and spread, independent of the genuine norms of speaking and writing.

The End of Men? In 1950, roughly one in 20 men of prime working age was not working - Today that ratio is about one in five, the highest ever recorded.

In Minnesota, cops are now arresting people for unpaid credit card and even medical debts, even though they committed no crime. In many cases, judges set bail at the amount owed: "So long as [you've] got unpaid bills, the threat is there."

I think its fair to say, if six months ago, I had gone up to Congress and I had said we need to crack down on oil companies and we need to spend more money on technology in case of a catastrophic spill, there are folks up there who would have said this is big-government and wasteful spending.

Mellified Man: Some elderly men in Arabia would submit themselves to a process of mummification in honey to create a healing confection. The process would start before death: The donor would stop eating any food other than honey, going as far as to bathe in the substance.
Among all the Chesapeake Bay's polluters, one group in particular stands out: The Amish.

People tend to have a visceral reaction to the sight of books piled ten feet high and left to rot, strewn about a classroom floor. They seem to have more sympathy for books than for the children wholl never have the chance to use them.

The Misconception: Fines curb bad behavior. The Truth: If you perceive the cost of a fine as less than the social cost of the bad behavior, it will cause the bad behavior to increase.
Creationists, climate deniers and others of their ilk are wrong, but they're not crazy. Such beliefs are simply the result of the way normal people think. Understanding this can help us fight them.

Neither bad apples nor good eggs, but soft fruit that can easily turn from ripe to rotten: Most people have no robust character at all, "good" or "evil." Instead their actions are dictated by circumstance.

Yay! YouTube announces that it will allow the Fair Use Defense. Users claiming fair use in videos previously taken down due to a copyright claim will be restored, and the claimant forced to file a formal complaint under DMCA.

When it comes to the tuning of instruments, nature drops a giant mathematical hairball in our path. Musicians and composers have been trying to dislodge it for centuries without success.
It is 550 feet tall and a mile wide. It altered ecosystems 1,000 miles away. All the pyramids at Giza could easily fit inside of it. Songs were written in its honor. Stand in awe of the Grand Coulee.

With Tax Day approaching you'll hear a lot about the 47% of households who pay no federal income taxes. This has become shorthand for the notion that the wealthy face a much higher tax burden while growing numbers of Americans are effectively on the dole. Neither one of those ideas is true.

The collapse of Velocity signals the end of a 50 year super-cycle in lending. The government is giving free money to the banks, but they're just sitting on it. As long as this continues, no matter how much money the government pumps into the economy, it might as well be pushing on a wet noodle.
